DOC.HEAD: Bomb Was Sent Through Mail, Postal Inspectors Confirm

Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with postal inspectors confirming bomb was sent through mail; picks up 2nd graf, `Washington County ...' SUBS 13th graf, `Investigators interviewed ...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with inspection service spokesman comment; picks up 14th graf, `The carrier ...'; DELETES outdated grafs 17-20, ```We're relatively ... ' picks up 21st graf, `Doctors said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday interviewed neighbors of a county judge and a letter carrier who delivered a package to his apartment, but found no leads into the bomb attack that wounded the judge, authorities said. Postal inspectors confirmed Saturday night that the pipe bomb was delivered through the mail. Washington County Circuit Judge John P. Corderman's condition was upgraded to good at Washington County Hospital, one day after a pipe bomb sent shrapnel into his hand and groin and damaged his eardrums. Dr. Charles Chaney said the judge's ears were still ringing from the blast, but his hearing had improved. Corderman now suffers a 25 percent hearing loss in both ears, down from a loss of as much as 75 percent initially, Chaney said. ``His sense of humor remains intact,'' the physician said. `` When told of the holes in both eardrums, he quipped, `There goes scuba diving.''' Postal inspectors, agents of the FBI and the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, and Hagerstown police investigating the bombing believe it wasn't related to four parcel bombs delivered in the Southeast in the past week, Police Lt. Robert Frick said. Two of those bombs exploded, killing a federal judge in a Birmingham, Ala., suburb Dec. 16 and an alderman who was also a civil rights attorney in Savannah on Monday. Bombs were found and defused last week at the Jacksonville, Fla., chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the federal courthouse in Atlanta. Investigators are focusing on a possible racial motivation in those cases. Frick said investigators didn't have a lead theory in the Hagerstown bombing. ``It's so early in the investigation,'' he said. ``We haven't fixed our investigation on a particular track. ``From what I know, (Corderman) doesn't have any idea who may have wanted to do this to him,'' he said. Frick said investigators were reviewing Corderman's cases. Authorities said they saw no link with the Southeast bombings, but said the attack could have been a copycat crime. Authorities believe a second unexploded bomb found in the apartment was delivered in the same package as the pipe bomb. That bomb was disarmed, and Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms officers took it and other evidence to the agency's laboratory in Rockville. The U.S. Postal Inspection Service confirmed that the pipe bomb, packaged in a Christmas food gift box, was sent through the mail and not through some other delivery service, said spokesman Paul Griffo in Washington. ``It basically changes the picture of the investigation,'' Griffo said. ``Now the Postal Inspection Service will be the lead agency in the investigation because we've determined that the bomb arrived through the mail and not through a delivery person.'' The inspection service stopped short, however, of naming letter carrier Robert L. Miller Sr., the only carrier on Corderman's route, as the person who delivered the bomb. Earlier Saturday, investigators interviewed Miller, who said he delivered a flat, rectangular box to Corderman's downtown apartment about 12:45 p.m. Friday, nearly two hours before the 2:30 p.m. explosion. Miller said he left the box leaning against the door when no one answered. The carrier said he believed the box contained perishable food because the cardboard had a waxy, oily texture. ``They showed me a picture of a blown-up Hickory Farms box with his name on it, but I don't know if I delivered a Hickory Farms box or not. It just looked like a normal package that came from a business,'' said Miller, 42. ``They keep asking me about postage and return addresses. I don't know. I think there was a return address, but I'm not sure,'' he said. Doctors said the judge, who had been in stable condition after surgery Friday to remove shrapnel, could be released from the hospital as early as Christmas Day. Chaney said doctors removed pieces of lead-colored pipe from Corderman's groin and right hand and reconstructed the top half of the middle finger on the judge's right hand, which had lost its tip. Several judges and other officials visited Corderman along with members of his family, who have declined to comment. Corderman also refused interviews. ``He's in very good spirits ,'' County Circuit Judge Daniel Moylan said. ``He's very grateful that he's alive.'' Corderman, who had been a judge for 12 years, was known as one of the toughest judges in the county. He was known for handing down harsh sentences, especially in drug-related cases. He also has been an outspoken advocate of gun control and has spoken out on controversial issues such as club gambling.
